issue.title: Signing URLs for improved security
issue.body:
Pippin asked me to go ahead and open an issue here for discussion on a new implementation for improving the security of URLs that I built out as an add-on at the moment. Considering the implications of something like this, it'd be ideal to roll it into the core plugin, but may require breaking some currently valid URLs.

The basic premise is that URLs can be signed using a unique string, in this case `wp_salt()`, and when requested, the token can be checked to ensure none of the variables in the query string have been tampered with. This allows for passing non-sensitive data through the URL in the clear and being certain that it hasn't been changed. It essentially allows for more secure and concise URLs.

### Code

My implementation is available here for anyone wanting to try it out and offer feedback on how it could be improved or integrated: https://github.com/bradyvercher/EDD-Signed-URLs

The first three functions simply hook into EDD to modify and check the URLs, while the last three functions provide the API for signing URLs.

The concept will work with any URL structure, so my method of condensing everything into a colon delimited `eddfile` query arg isn't required (and that arg could even be renamed with a simple filter if desired).

### Breakage

As far as potentially breaking changes, existing URLs that haven't expired would quit working with this solution. It might be possible to run things side by side for a short while, but the current method would need to be deprecated at some point.

This would also decrease the reliance on using the `download_key` to look up a payment, instead using actual payment IDs, which might make things a little easier to work with. In that case, the current API utilizing the `download_key` might need to be augmented, or a new solution could be run side by side. I'm not sure if anyone is using the existing functions directly or not.

### Improvements

In any case, we're opening this up to see if anyone has ideas on implementing a solution like this without breaking anything. Feedback about improvements, suggestions on the default URL structure (is it worth trying to simplify?), and increasing security is welcome.

Feel free to correct me if I got anything wrong, Pippin.

comment.body:
Hmm, that's a good point. Without the separate URL parameters, it's more difficult to determine the expiration dates.

What if we were to add an expiration date parameter that is checked only if the token is verified? The expiration date could be included as its own parameter and also part of the token creation, that way it can't be changed.

issue.title: [WIP] major refactoring of architecture
issue.body:
|Q            |A  |
|---          |---|
|Bug Fix?     |yes|
|New Feature? |yes |
|BC Breaks?   |*yes!** |
|Deprecations?|no |
|Fixed Tickets| #26  |
|License      |MIT|

This a major refactoring of the search system architecture.

In summary the following has changed;

## ConditionOptimizers 

Formatters are renamed to ConditionOptimizers, and have an optional priority for sorting.

## Input processor changes

View to normalized value transformation now happens in the Input processor.
The SearchConditionBuilder does not use this technique.

Range bounds are now validated when processing, and not as an *optional* process afterwards.

To make InputProcessors reusable, configuration must be provided as first parameter of `process()`.

And last, all processors when testing now share the same assertions to ensure a correct result.

## Values 

To make locking the SearchCondition state easier and enforce a stricter OOP architecture value objects are now immutable and marked final.

`PatternMatch::getViewValue()` is removed as this method doesn't make sense for a string-only value object.

ValueGroups no longer keep track of errors, but ask the ValuesBag's and nested groups instead.

## Symfony validator

The Symfony validator extension is **finally** moved to its own repository and package.
As constraint validation is no longer needed for validating range-bounds.

## TODO

- [ ] Add support for locking the ValuesGroup and FieldSet.
- [ ] Check documentation for inconsistent usage of terms.
- [ ] Make tests for exporters uniform (same like input).
- [ ] Look for missing tests and documentation.
- [ ] Allow removing errors from a ValuesBag.

'error' is a method on the old event emitter aswell that we are maintaining BC for. So when you are using `.error` you are using the event emitter and not the promise.

It's too huge of a break to remove the eventemitter completely, but i suppose we could have some kind of flag to turn it off perhaps.

issue.title: (#3316) - more changes() documentation
issue.body:
The `changes()` documentation was looking kind of weak, so I added this.

Although I'm becoming convinced that people should just use `changes()` as an indication that *something* changed, rather than trying to understand the changes feed itself. E.g. if you are trying to maintain an in-memory mirror of DOM elements, then just blow it away every time something changes and run `allDocs` all over again. I believe I am even screwing this up in the ember-pouch plugin, so I need to go back and rewrite what I already wrote over there.

issue.title: Implement Tabs component
issue.body:
![screen shot 2014-11-11 at 15 26 29](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/110953/4995210/2143c9a2-69b7-11e4-9db0-ff4154f8e4b7.png)

* Tabs are presented as a single row.
* Tabs should not be nested. Content in a tab should not consist of another set of tabbed content.
* A set of tabs contains at minimum a pair of tabs and no more than six tabs.
* Tabs control the display of content in a consistent location.
* The tab corresponding to the visible content is highlighted.
* Tabs are grouped together and the group of tabs is in turn connected with their content.

Polymer: http://www.polymer-project.org/components/paper-tabs/demo.html
Angular: https://material.angularjs.org/#/demo/material.components.tabs
CSS: http://codepen.io/keremciu/details/EgGcu/

More visuals:

![](http://material-design.storage.googleapis.com/publish/v_1/quantumexternal/0Bx4BSt6jniD7SWtvczhLbU11Uzg/components_tabs_usage_mobile1.png)

issue.title: [Vote] Which authentification mechanisms should we provide?
issue.body:
We currently provide:

- "formed based" authentication with Spring Security, which we have extended so you can invalidate sessions, have a better cookie theft feature, etc...
- OAuth2 authentification, which requires us to have our own server side implementation in MongoDB (and soon in Cassandra)

Both options are good and are two different approaches.

Now we have 4 other options that are currently opened tickets:

- #684 Support Spring Social
- #813 Use Json Web Tokens
- #892 x-auth-token authentication method
- #903 use Angular Token

Obviously, we can't support all of them, so we need to choose. From my personal point of view, what we already have is good enough, and I don't know if those other mechanisms are good/secured/useful.

So I'm opening this ticket to start a discussion and a vote, and close the mechanisms that we will not support.

comment.body:
..or at least don't close the poll yet. What is already in jhipster is fine for now. I wouldn't change much yet after only hearing from a few people on a poll that wasn't tweeted about. 
Jwt, oauth2 + openid connect is a powerful authentication/authorization combination with ietf standards and support from big players (jwt is authorization not authentication in itself but openid connect is authentication). I admit it isn't simple but I think it's worth it at the right time. 
If you do need to change direction right now, I wouldn't go far from what you currently have. 

I'm very interested in this topic and only saw this poll now!

issue.title: Trick for automatically serializing eagerly loaded associations?
issue.body: Just a minor issue that I'm struggling with at the moment. It appears that the default instance implementation of toJSON detects and automatically serializes any eagerly loaded associations on the model. However, the name that the associations are loaded under is the capitalized and pluralized name of the association. So if I have a 'Topic' model with a 'Category' association such that `Topic.belongsTo(Category)`, if I eagerly load the category with the topic, I get `topic.Category`. Obviously this is a trivial example but I'm wondering if there is some way to access a list of eagerly loaded associations from within the toJSON() instance method so that I can programmatically rename and serialize all of the eagerly loaded associations?

issue.title: Following hoplon Getting Started, fails on Step 2
issue.body:
Hi there,
I was really excited to try out hoplon, but ran into this snag:

     Task 2: Compile the project.

     $ boot development

However, this fails with:

    java.lang.RuntimeException: No reader function for tag tailrecursion.boot.core/version

I tried upgrading boot:

    Retrieving boot-2.0.0-rc4.jar from http://clojars.org/repo/
    #https://github.com/boot-clj/boot
    #Thu Jan 01 01:58:12 CET 2015
    BOOT_CLOJURE_VERSION=1.6.0
    BOOT_VERSION=2.0.0-rc4

But just received the same error.

I am stuck, and in need of sleep. :)  If anyone can figure out what is going wrong here I would love to move onto exploring hoplon.

Thanks,

Rohni

comment.body:
Hi, sorry that you're having difficulties!  The problem is that the Hoplon tutorials assume you're using boot 1, at [tailrecursion/boot](https://github.com/tailrecursion/boot).

Unfortunately we haven't ported Hoplon too boot 2 - the one at boot-clj/boot - yet, so if you want to both use hoplon and boot 2, you need to have booth boots installed.

Personally I have boot 1 installed as 'boot1' on my system, that way I can do `boot1 development` etc.

Sorry for the confusion!  We'll have Hoplon ported to boot2 soon and then this will stop being confusing.

issue.title: Confused about M:M hasMany
issue.body:
I have had a m:m working as:
```
  Roles.hasMany(models.Users)
  Users.hasMany(models.Roles)
```

Since I want to grab the user's roles I wanted an alias so first I tried:
```
  Roles.hasMany(models.Users, {as: "users"})
  Users.hasMany(models.Roles, {as: "roles""})
```
But this yielded:
```
Error: Cyclic dependency found. 'Roles' is dependent of itself.
Dependency Chain: Roles -> Users => Roles
    at visit (/Users/bkaplan/si/vi-security-users/node_modules/sequelize-extra/node_modules/sequelize/node_modules/toposort-class/toposort.js:74:27)
    at /Users/bkaplan/si/vi-security-users/node_modules/sequelize-extra/node_modules/sequelize/node_modules/toposort-class/toposort.js:96:25
```

After reading the docs closer I see that through is required when using an alias. But still this error message is a bit opaque. 

So I next tried:
```
  Roles.hasMany(models.Users, {as: "users", through: "Roles_Users"})
  Users.hasMany(models.Roles, {as: "roles", through: "Roles_Users"})
```
But this yielded:
```
Uncaught exception: [RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded]
```
With no other stack trace.

Is there something basic I am missing? (Assuming this is enough context)

comment.body:
It all looks correct with the through defined.
I haven't seen a stack size error before. Is there a stack for the range error?

issue.title: Chrome on Windows disables non-web store HTTPS Everywhere on restart
issue.body:
Steps to reproduce:

1. In Chrome on Windows, install HTTPS Everywhere directly from EFF (download the .crx, drag and drop into Extensions page).
2. Restart Chrome.

Expected result:

HTTPS Everywhere stays installed.

Actual result:

On next startup, a notice appears in the upper right saying "Unsupported extensions disabled. To make Chrome safer, we disabled some extensions that aren't listed in the Chrome Web Store and may have been added without your knowledge.

 - HTTPS Everywhere"

On the Extensions page, HTTPS Everywhere is greyed out, disabled, and the checkbox to re-enable it is greyed out. Enabling developer mode doesn't fix it, nor does dragging in the .crx again. Deleting the extension and dragging back in the .crx works until the next restart.

We should ask Google about this.

comment.body:
There are two options to workaround this.

One is extracting the CRX to a new folder in the computer and use programing mode to load the extension from the folder.

Another one is, the one I use for archival purposes, download the CRX from Chrome webstore using "Give me CRX": https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/give-me-crx/acpimoebmfjpfnbhjgdgiacjfebmmmci

Apparently there is some method of certificate authentication in CRX files and those downloaded from eff's website mismatch the copies at google's servers.

Regards,
NewEraCracker

issue.title: abandoned session locks

comment.body:
@nicktacular it looks like what I am experiencing are locks being stuck forever after a timeout or something... IE, if my script dies with a 500 error (php timeout), that session is now stuck forever.

Correct me if I am wrong, but anytime my script doesn't end execution gracefully after have already opened a session, subsequent requests with that key will hang.

Here is an example from my HTTP logs...

You can see the script dies from another cause (script timed out), which CAN/WILL happen. But the issue is this lock is now stuck forever, as you can see the following requests all die with a lock timeout.

````
[Thu Jan 01 15:03:22 2015] [warn] [client xxx] mod_fcgid: read data timeout in 31 seconds, referer: https://xxx
[Thu Jan 01 15:03:22 2015] [error] [client xxx] Premature end of script headers: index.php, referer: https://xxx
[Thu Jan 01 15:04:30 2015] [warn] [client xxx] mod_fcgid: stderr: PHP Notice:  Could not acquire lock for jdauj4v9766meag73iifcj7c72 in /usr/share/php-mongo-session/MongoSession.php on line 483
[Thu Jan 01 15:05:38 2015] [warn] [client xxx] mod_fcgid: stderr: PHP Notice:  Could not acquire lock for jdauj4v9766meag73iifcj7c72 in /usr/share/php-mongo-session/MongoSession.php on line 483, referer: https://xxx
...
````

You said you don't end up with any stuck locks though? Even in this scenario?

Let me know your thoughts... I am thinking some sort of garbage collection is needed to clean up these "dead locks".

issue.title: go/ssa/interp: breaks on reflect implementation of Go tip
issue.body:
Running ssadump on [this go program](http://play.golang.org/p/JHUgaI-2sq) produces a panic: 

    panic: interface conversion: interface is reflect.rtype, not *reflect.rtype

With go gc 1.4 on GNU/Linux there is none. 

The full invocation, output produced, and golang version is given in [this gist](https://gist.github.com/rocky/6f4f1955cdf8addaeb92). 

Looking at the Go code:

    u8 reflect.Type = reflect.TypeOf(uint8(0))
    byteSlice reflect.Type = reflect.SliceOf(u8)

I am just as confused as ssadump. Here is *reflect.SliceOf* in *reflect/type.go*:

    func SliceOf(t Type) Type {
    typ := t.(*rtype)
    ...

The ssadump error message makes sense to me in that the passed-in type is a `reflect.rtype`, not and `*reflect.rtype` which is what  appears to be the use in *reflect.SliceOf*. 

So what is it in Go that makes it okay to have these things not give a type error?

comment.body: Never mind. I see how to do this in externals.go. For example: "(*sync.Pool).Get".

issue.title: smarter BoundsError reporting
issue.body:
BoundsError() made me sad (so I fixed it)

this adds argument information to intrinsic bounds checking operations, optimized to have no added impact on the runtime cost, in the common case of not having an error

lots of examples (because there's a lot of cases this handles):
```
julia> a,b,c = 1,2
ERROR: BoundsError(
  of (1,2)
  at index [3]
  )
 in indexed_next at /Volumes/Lion/Users/jameson/Documents/julia/usr/lib/julia/sys.dylib

julia> f(::Any, ::Any, ::Any, args...) = Any
f (generic function with 1 method)

julia> invoke(f, (Any, Any, Any), 1, 1, 1)
ERROR: BoundsError(
  of (Int64,Int64...)
  at index [3]
  )
 in typeinf at ./inference.jl:1393
 in typeinf_ext at ./inference.jl:1242

julia> [][1,2]
ERROR: BoundsError(
  of 0-element Array{Any,1}
  at index [1,2]
  )

comment.body:
just a quick 1st brain dump:
# possible ways: 
a) Auto-discovery (let a crawler find participating websites)
  -- maybe later, too much hassle in the beginning, fiddly error handling etc 
b) form with url input where participating people can enter their sites
  -- easy to implement, simple db-or-else storage, but spam-check is needed and a way to verify that indeed a key is placed

issue.title: Unknown method: DisplayPinCode is not a valid method of interface org.bluez.Agent1
issue.body:
Blueman from git does not allow me to use a bluetooth keyboard. In bluetoothd logs, I see this:

```
aep-haswell bluetoothd[655]: Agent replied with an error: org.freedesktop.DBus.Error.UnknownMethod, Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/site-packages/dbus/service.py", line 654, in _message_cb
        (candidate_method, parent_method) = _method_lookup(self, method_name, interface_name)
    File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/site-packages/dbus/service.py", line 246, in _method_lookup
        raise UnknownMethodException('%s is not a valid method of interface %s' % (method_name, dbus_interface))
    UnknownMethodException: org.freedesktop.DBus.Error.UnknownMethod: Unknown method: DisplayPinCode is not a valid method of interface org.bluez.Agent1
```

comment.body:
I have just tested this branch with that keyboard. Indeed, it prints a pincode that, when typed, leads to the HID authentication popup. If I authorize the device, it works. However, in the terminal output, there is a traceback.

issue.title: ENH: sparse: speedup LIL matrix slicing
issue.body:
The current implementation for slicing LIL matrices is very pessimal. Replace it with a more optimal implementation.

Gives a factor of ~1/density speedup:
```
In []: A = rand(3000, 3000, density=1e-3, format="lil")

# Before (9ccc68475)
In [4]: %timeit A[::2,::-2]
10 loops, best of 3: 87.5 ms per loop

# After (d47e27b0)
In [4]: %timeit A[::2,::-2]
1000 loops, best of 3: 603 µs per loop
```
Gives speedups also for smaller slices:
```
# Before
In [5]: %timeit A[3,:]
1000 loops, best of 3: 213 µs per loop
In [6]: %timeit A[:,3]
1000 loops, best of 3: 901 µs per loop
In [7]: %timeit A[1:5,1:5]
10000 loops, best of 3: 83.3 µs per loop

# After
In [5]: %timeit A[3,:]
10000 loops, best of 3: 38.8 µs per loop
In [6]: %timeit A[:,3]
1000 loops, best of 3: 702 µs per loop
In [7]: %timeit A[1:5,1:5]
10000 loops, best of 3: 40.3 µs per loop
```
(Column slices in LIL are still problematic, but that's due to the matrix format.)

**EDIT** updated benchmarks

Looking at the dependencies up to now, packaging itself should be relatively straightforward once makki gives the go-ahead.

issue.title: Add RabbitMQ monitor to alert when count(channel) > count(connection)
issue.body:
Having any RabbitMQ connection servicing more than a single channel indicates a problem with agent <-> RabbitMQ communication.  We need an alert any time this occurs.

Expected behavior:
```
# rabbitmqctl list_connections channels | sort -n | tail -n1 
1
```

Indicates a problem:
```
# rabbitmqctl list_connections channels | sort -n | tail -n1 
186833
```

issue.title: About Array function indexOf
issue.body:
Line 644
~~~
 if(hoursDisabled.index(i)....
~~~
It will not work at ie8
we can change it use jquery function index
like this
~~~
if($(hoursDisabled).index(i)
~~~
the same as line 678

comment.body:
@superchangme 
Or maybe:
```
if (hoursDisabled.indexOf(i) !== -1) continue;
```
needs changing to:
```
if (jQuery.inArray(i, hoursDisabled) !== -1) continue;
```

Likewise for:
```
if (minutesDisabled.indexOf(i) !== -1) continue;
```
changing to:
```
if (jQuery.inArray(i, minutesDisabled) !== -1) continue;
```
to let jquery do the hardwork.

issue.title: Add Positive assumption helper for gamma function, Fixes #8524
issue.body:
The Positive assumption helper for gamma function is missing:
So the the following code returns None:

```python
>>> n = Symbol('n', real=True, positive=True)
>>> gamma(n).is_positive
```
With this PR, Positive assumption works well for gamma function.

Fixes #8524

issue.title: Best location for classes
issue.body: @DominikGuzei what is the best locations for classes. is it the lib or server folder?

comment.body:
@joshua1 what do you mean? Classes are a basic programming construct you can use anywhere. This library just simplifies working with classical inheritance in Javascript similar to how Coffeescript does.

Where you put your code depends on how you want to structure the overall application, that's pretty much a matter of taste or conventions. E.g: I never use a `lib` folder and also don't think it's a great naming convention because it's way to general and just shows that you have no clear idea about this code.
